verdict.summary: Almost always caused by a mismatch between the tsconfig options and the installed TypeScript version. The option either does not exist yet in the user's version or was renamed/removed.

dead_ends.action: Downgrading TypeScript to make the unknown option valid
dead_ends.why_fails: Downgrading introduces incompatibilities with the rest of the codebase and dependencies that may require newer TS features. The option may have been removed entirely, so no version makes it valid.
dead_ends.common_misconception: Developers assume the option existed in older versions and was removed, when often it was added in newer versions and their installed TS is too old.

dead_ends.action: Copying tsconfig.json from a tutorial without checking TS version
dead_ends.why_fails: Tutorial configs often use bleeding-edge options like verbatimModuleSyntax (TS 5.0+), moduleDetection (TS 4.7+), or allowImportingTsExtensions (TS 5.0+). The option does not exist in the installed version.
dead_ends.common_misconception: tsconfig options are assumed to be universal across all TypeScript versions.

dead_ends.action: Adding skipLibCheck or @ts-ignore to suppress the error
dead_ends.why_fails: TS5023 is a config-level parse error, not a type error in source code. skipLibCheck and @ts-ignore only suppress type-checking errors. Config errors cannot be suppressed.
dead_ends.common_misconception: Developers conflate TypeScript config errors with type-checking errors. Config errors are fatal and cannot be ignored.

workarounds.action: Check installed TS version and use version-appropriate options
workarounds.how: Run 'npx tsc --version' to check the installed version. Consult the TypeScript release notes for when the option was introduced. Common mappings: verbatimModuleSyntax requires >=5.0, moduleDetection requires >=4.7, allowImportingTsExtensions requires >=5.0.
workarounds.tradeoff: Requires knowing which TS version introduced which option

workarounds.action: Replace the unknown option with its predecessor
workarounds.how: verbatimModuleSyntax replaces isolatedModules + importsNotUsedAsValues. moduleDetection replaces heuristics from the module option. Remove the unknown option and use the older equivalent for your TS version.
workarounds.tradeoff: Predecessor options may have slightly different semantics

workarounds.action: Use extends with a version-matched base tsconfig
workarounds.how: Install a base config package: 'npm install -D @tsconfig/node20' then add '"extends": "@tsconfig/node20/tsconfig.json"' to your tsconfig.json. These base configs only use options valid for the target environment.

frequently_confused_with.distinction: TS5023 means the option name is entirely unknown to the compiler, while TS6046 means the option exists but the value provided for it is invalid.
